comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Ah Valentines Day!  

I hope the Mother-in-Law-from-Hell (at left) didn't ruin the honeymoon, and was cropped out of the final print.

comment.author: 43724934@N06
comment._content: both women have lovely ankles, one knows about life, the other but a student eager and excited

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I suspect that this is a pic of celebrities who have just arrived in Sydney. The young woman here looks like a slightly slim 1920s version of Gladys Moncrieff. The nose and eyes and even elements of her facial musculature appear to match Moncrieff's ...check these pics...particularly the last one, which shows how at certain angles and under given lighting conditions Moncrieff's cheeks and jaw look slimmer than they appear in most other pics of her - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an23372012 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=891552 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=74460 ; nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn3601306 ...If this were Moncrieff, then the man with her is definitely not her husband - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=36744

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: I have just re-dated the photograph 1926-1930, because most of the Hood collection was 1930's but this is before 1930 when the hemlines started to drop again like the economy. We have a photograph of Gladys Moncrieff taken about the same time - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemPopLarger.aspx?itemid=891562
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 28853714@N05
comment._content: "Photo of us on our honeymoon, with mom before she mysteriously went overboard and disappeared."

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Having given up on my Gladys Moncrieff theory, I'm now convinced these two are either athletes (eg. tennis players) or ballet dancers.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales

comment._content: Yes or JC Williamson stars !
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Well here's some more pics of the cruelly maligned mother-in-law! I entertained the possibility that she might have been a retired Russian ballerina who'd moved on to choreography or who perhaps just cracked the whip during stretching workouts. But just going on these pics I'd say she might have had German connections (ie. note her swastika brooch) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10554 [6410] ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10558 [6413]...the young boy in the cubs outfit might have come to meet grandma who's arrived from overseas...but I wonder whether this other pic might have been taken on the same occasion...I can spot at least one cub among the scouts - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10550 [6409] Here's yet another pic of her - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10570 [6419] Maybe the same stairway in this pic...the florists must have been busy! - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10571 [6420]... just going on the style of numbering on the pillars, this group might have been on the same ship - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10563 [6416] Work in progress...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Any ideas re the elderly woman's hat? It's certainly distinctive.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's the cropped version without the cruelly maligned mother-in-law (!) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10566 [6417]

comment.author: 28853714@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02]  I've seen hats like that before.  Makes no sense to me.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Apologies for maligning the mother-in-law. Perhaps she is The Ballet-Madame-from-Hell, or The Dresser-from-Hell? The hat makes her look like a Gumnut Baby. Which makes me think May Gibbs, aged forty-something?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Having spent at least 100 hours on this one...with nothing much to show for it...my latest theory...guess (!)... is that the couple might be the American actors Ruth Nugent (1902-?1978) and Alan Bunce (?1900-1965), who were both J.C. Williamson stars. They were also married. Per the digitised newspapers they arrived in Sydney on the Aorangi on 4 January, 1929. This pic of Nugent and Bunce appeared in the Sydney Mail on 8 May, 1929, accompanying a review of the comedy 'Pigs', which was then playing at the Criterion Theatre - news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1302&dat=19290508&... Note the Sydney Mail article also refers to Miss Gertrude Augarde who played 'the irascible old grandmother'...maybe she is our cruelly maligned mother-in-law. Monsieur Google kindly informs me that the Bunce and Nugent family records are held at the Houghton Library at Harvard University...the collection evidently includes quite a few pics of Nugent and Bunce which might perhaps enable my theory to be verified/refuted. ? This 1953 pic of Alan Bunce is interesting - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Alan_Bunce_Peg_Lynch_Ethel_and... ... compare with the non mother-in-law SLNSW version - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10566

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Sorry "quasymody" - I was hoping and it all sounded great but Ruth Nugent photographed at around the same time is pictured in the famous Billy Rose theatre collection at the New York Public Library: digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm...
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Yes, I've reluctantly had to concede that my latest guess is also a dud! In the cool light of day I can see that Alan Bunce's ears just don't match up with this chap's...no matter what angle you view them from...no matter how much you allow for cartilage growth in later life, etc...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here I go again...this time my guess is that the pics in the range hood_06409 - hood_06420 were taken on the same occasion...if this is correct then we at least have a few more clues to go on...eg these passengers - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10555 [hood_06411] ; the scouts farewelling the liner - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10550 [hood_06409] ; these passengers - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10559 [hood_06414] ; this group - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10563 [hood_0616] ; and this woman - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10571 [hood_06420] During the 1920s and 1930s the Sydney society magazine the Home often published pics of people arriving and departing on ocean liners. The Sydney Morning Herald also occasionally published pics of arrivals/departures, though with the SMH the pics tended to involve 'important people' in the worlds of business and politics etc rather than well heeled travellers and socialites. I'd say that some of the other Sydney newspapers might also have published pics of arrivals/departures...many of the other Australian capital city dailies occasionally did so. Note that the Sam Hood pics which immediately precede this sequence (assuming it is a sequence) involve a flood at Narrabeen which evidently occurred in April 1927...this might be significant... alas I don't have easy access to a complete collection of the Home for the 1927-1930 period...ditto the Sydney newspapers which aren't on Trove... ...work in progress...

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Hello again, Quasymody! Yes Hood's photos are in series and often interrelated, however not every series is in sequence. May I suggest if you can go to your local Library, that you check The Labor Daily (microfilm) - library.sl.nsw.gov.au/search~S1?/Xlabor%20daily&searc...
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: PS 1927-1930 is spot on for the woman's dress
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/8228852663/in/photostream] - The date is 8 February, 1928. The ship is the Narkunda, departing Sydney for London. The mother-in-law is Miss Charles-Fairfax 'of Sydney and London'. The wolf-cub we see in these pics acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10554 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10558 is from the 1st Petersham Troop (name not indicated). Miss Charles-Fairfax was evidently given a send off by the scouts, who I gather we see in this pic - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10550 . This SMH item indicates the date of her departure and gives background on her scouting connections - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16440590 . I now tend to suspect that her swastika brooch was maybe a good luck charm or something similar and that it would not have signified any Nazi connections/affiliations, etc. (remember this was 1928, when the Nazis were still just a rabble and largely unknown outside Germany). There's quite a bit in the digitised newspapers on Miss Charles-Fairfax...various pics, eg. - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16723421 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16803337 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16740507 (next to Santa Claus)...and this 1936 SMH obit item - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17239577 ; Here's her Obituaries Australia entry - oa.anu.edu.au/obituary/fairfax-caroline-elizabeth-carrie-... Source: 'P&O Portraits', the Home, 2/4/1928, p. 57 - which has a pic of Miss Charles-Fairfax with the unnamed wolf-cub (a cropped version of acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10558). Missed this one on my first trawl thru the Home...that was only 250 hours of trawling ago! ...work still in progress re the 'newlyweds'...assuming they were also passengers, presumably they're listed here - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16440131

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] ALLELUYA! Well found you! Miss Charles-Fairfax was NEVER the Mother-in-law-from-Hell - I take it ALL back. Her obituary is full of Good Works, bless her. Good luck finding the couple - I hope it doesn't take another 250 hours! One thing - was it customary to call unmarried ladies by their father's (hyphenated) name? Miss Charles-Fairfax was really Caroline Elizabeth (Carrie) Fairfax (1860–1936).

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I think you might be right re the form of her name...or at least that's probably the correct form as prescribed by Doggeselley's Handbook of English Etiquette (1925 edition). If she's still circulating in the ethers somewhere I'm sure she's taken all comments made in good fun. I'd say you're safe from stray lightning bolts!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10570 - the two gents on the right in this pic look a bit like her cousins ... but this is a bit of a guess...and given I've already shredded my credibility thru reckless guessing (see above!), I won't go too far down that road again... oa.anu.edu.au/obituary/fairfax-sir-james-oswald-6356 and oa.anu.edu.au/obituary/fairfax-geoffrey-evan-13781

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Thanks for finding the identity of Miss Charles-Fairfax! I'll add her name to the records. The swastika brooch would undoubtedly have no Nazi meaning as Hitler was not even a blip on the Empire's radar at this stage.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content:
I thought at first that if the "newlyweds" were indeed related to Miss Charles-Fairfax, it seemed to narrow the young couple down to three possibilities, if they were married in Sydney in 1928:
1. Warwick O. Fairfax married Marcie E. Wilson, Woollahra (most likely)
2. George H. Petersen married Ethel V. Fairfax, Orange
3. Walter E.A. Willey married Estelle E. Fairfax, Hurstville
Then I read the passenger list! Warwick Fairfax is not on the passenger list
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: And also thanks for identifying the two Fairfax men, one of whom died in the year of this photograph so it was the last time they were all together probably
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Having been briefly cured of guessing...well here I go again! ...this time my theory is that the couple are Clive Evatt (Snr) and his wife Marjorie (nee Andreas)...and if this is correct, then they were indeed newlyweds, having married a week or so earlier, in January 1928...out of all the listed Narkunda passengers they are right up there among the 'possibles'. Here's a pic of Evatt taken a few years later (the lips are quite distinctive, pity about the bad hair day) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17231983 ; there's also a certain resemblance here - www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/1fb6e... ; The SLNSW collection includes dozens of low resolution scans of pics of Clive Evatt, some of which also include Marjorie. But they were taken some 20 years on, in the late 1940s and early 1950s...and on a quick run thru, I haven't been able to find one which might settle the matter...maybe there are more contemporary pics around somewhere...in the yet to be digitised newspapers (!)...or in the Home maybe...or in a sporting newspaper...Evatt was a rugby league player of note in the early 1920s...he was good enough to play a couple of games as hooker for the Blues...pity they didn't have saturation coverage of footy back then or there'd be heaps of pics of the young Evatt around the place...of course later in life, when he left politics and returned to the bar, Clive Evatt Snr became a larger than life Sydney legal figure...if my guess is correct (and I'm 80% sure it is) there'd be thousands of people still around who should be able to identify him...if my guess is correct... Here's the alternative version again for reference - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10566 This ?mid 1940s pic of Clive Evatt Snr is a good match - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29763623 Here's a pic of Clive Evatt Snr and Marjorie taken in 1948 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=216430

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Note that Miss Elizabeth Macarthur-Onslow and her mother are also on the Narkunda's passenger list...I wonder whether that's who we see in this other Sam Hood pic from this sequence acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10563 - Compare the younger woman passenger on the lhs with the bridesmaid on the rhs in this Sam Hood pic - www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/3558678898/ ... zoom in here acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=153839&amp... ... this pic of her mother is maybe a bit inconclusive - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16626595

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: I have added this information to the records. Thank you again!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection
